Original Work [Lemmon, 2012] Market-Oriented Cloud Model [Lemmon, 2012] Contributions
A passivity framework to manage cloud computing systems from a market-oriented point of view is proposed.
Effect of Equilibrium Points in Stability Effect of Time-Varying w(k)
Original Work [Lemmon, 2012] Market-Oriented Cloud Model [Lemmon, 2012] Contributions
The routing of the consumers workload into the cloud is described by a market-oriented discrete-time model.
Servers communicate with brokers letting them know how busy they are.
Brokers distribute the consumers workload to be processed by the servers based on the current status of the servers.
This framework takes advantage of the passivity inherited by a system formed by interconnected passive subsystems.

Original Work [Lemmon, 2012] Market-Oriented Cloud Model [Lemmon, 2012] Contributions
The broker system is output strictly passive.
From passivity theory the origin of the interconnected system with w(k) = 0 is asymptotically stable.
Effect of Equilibrium Points in Stability Effect of Time-Varying w(k)

Effect of Equilibrium Points in Stability Effect of Time-Varying w(k)
Original Work [Lemmon, 2012] Market-Oriented Cloud Model [Lemmon, 2012] Contributions
We provide a mathematical justification to the use of Passivity theory.
We proof that an additional condition is required to guarantee the asymptotic stability of the system and proceed to formulate it.
We proof that the system is Input-to-State Stable (ISS) in presence of time-varying consumers workload.

At time step k = 100 the mean of w(k) is changed to = 25 and at k = 210 it goes back to = 2.
At k = 425 the mean goes to = 16 and at k = 632 it returns to = 2.

Effect of Equilibrium Points in Stability Effect of Time-Varying w(k)
We have presented an in depth analysis of the passivity framework introduced in [Lemmon, 2012] for power control and response time management in the cloud.
We have formally provided an additional condition for the asymptotic stability of the market-oriented cloud model.
Additional assumptions to justify the use of the passivity approach to guarantee asymptotic stability have been provided.
We have formally proven that the the cloud model is ISS in the presence of time-varying consumers workload vectors.

Let us study the broker system defined by (1) and (2), and let us define,
then, the system (1) may be rewritten as,

Assuming no active projection in (12), we note that the system is Linear Time Invariant (LTI). Based on [Lemmon, 2012] the origin with e1(k) = 0 is asymptotically stable. Since the system is LTI we conclude that it is Bounded-Input-Bounded-Output (BIBO) stable as well.

Similarly, the origin of the server system given by (5), (6) and (3) was proven to be stable with y(k) = 0. Assuming no active projection, the system is LTI, therefore, it is BIBO stable. Assuming an active projection in the server system the system matrix A becomes,
and the system is LTI, therefore it is BIBO stable.
